comms_internal: Alternative is “k'ul-caʕan” [house-obl.lat]. I chose the version with “INESS” because Gilles commented that the LAT variant is “careful speech” and also to observe a difference between the Ismailli dialect and Kryz proper.

comms_internal: Alternative is “rasul-a zina” [R.-iness COM]. The two markers are synonyms in comitative contexts. MRP: “-zına is exclusively comitative, -q́ına is instrumental wherever the context allows an instrumental interpretation, but can be used as comitative when the context excludes the instrumental reading”.

Alternative is “rasul-a zina” [R.-iness COM]. The two postpositions are synonyms in comitative contexts. sentence: aslan rasul-a q'ina sad san lu-car ʕuran taniş xhay-ce
glosses_en: PN PN-INESS INS one.N year this-ABL before known be.PF-PERF.M
back_translation_en: ‘Aslan got to know Rasul a year ago.’
back_translation_ru: ‘Аслан познакомился с Расулом год тому назад.’
comms_internal: Alternative is “rasul-a zina” [R.-iness COM]. The two markers are synonyms in comitative contexts. MRP: “-zına is exclusively comitative, -q́ına is instrumental wherever the context allows an instrumental interpretation, but can be used as comitative when the context excludes the instrumental reading”.
“RED” in the gloss is reduplication. As all other postpoistions, “ʕuni” requiress the inessive form in a, but the combination of “be” [NOM.PL] and “a” [INESS] yields “e”.

back_translation_en: ‘Aslan is trying to catch the cat.’
‘Aslan is dreaming of a new car.’

comms: Not included in the database because X is expressed as an NP-internal modifier.
comms_internal: In “zad-ini tur” “zad-ini” cannot be separated from “tur” by any phrase-external material. The only lexical items that can be inserted are phrase-internal, e.g. “lu zad-ini elmi tur” i.e. “the scientific name of this thing”.

As far as I understand, there is no paradigmatic contrast between the possessor-like form, so that the Instrumental marker “q'ina” combines with a slightly different form than in many other examples. Alternative is “xhiy zina” [water.INESS COM]. The two markers are synonyms in comitative contexts. MRP: “-zına is exclusively comitative, -q́ına is instrumental wherever the context allows an instrumental interpretation, but can be used as comitative when the context excludes the instrumental reading”.

sentence: aslan rix yerxh-id na tukan-ca ʕaç'-id
glosses_en: PN road H.cross.PF-AOR.M and shop-OBL.INESS enter.PF-AOR.M
back_translation_en: ‘Aslan crossed the road and entered the shop.’
back_translation_ru: ‘Аслан пересек дорогу и вошел в магазин.’
comms_internal: Very interesting case of syntactic copying. Azeri like Turkish, tolerates place names as objects of motion verbs. So you have a novel ‘binominative’ construction for S & P.
